text: Hey, this is somewhat of a vague question as I am largely unfamiliar with the Julia Geo community but what is the Julia geo package ecosystem like compared to Python - particularly to geopandas and folium? I desire to work with Julia for my data analysis but am curious if I will need to supplement my work with python packages via PyCall. Thanks all! _P.S. I am not asking exactly about community/adoption sort of stuff - Python has been around much longer than Julia so I don't expect Geo Julia to have as much. However, if it has the essentials, then heck yea! I can do my analysis in Julia!_ :juliaheartpulse-dark:

elements.text: Hey, this is somewhat of a vague question as I am largely unfamiliar with the Julia Geo community but what is the Julia geo package ecosystem like compared to Python - particularly to geopandas and folium? P.S. I am not asking exactly about community/adoption sort of stuff - Python has been around much longer than Julia so I don't expect Geo Julia to have as much. However, if it has the essentials, then heck yea! I can do my analysis in Julia!

text: <@U88813859> GeoDataFrames looks great, but I'm having issues with plotting after a reprojection. It might be my problem, since I'm learning about these things as I play with some data I have. I'll keep playing some more.

elements.text: GeoDataFrames looks great, but I'm having issues with plotting after a reprojection. It might be my problem, since I'm learning about these things as I play with some data I have. I'll keep playing some more.

text:
[ANN] GeoDataFrames 0.1 has also been released :tada: , see <https://github.com/evetion/GeoDataFrames.jl>. It's a simple wrapper on top of ArchGDAL that should make things easier. I saw a lot of questions/posts/issues on Slack/Discourse/Github on how to write shapefiles etc, while I needed a similar thing as well. It's still a work in progress, things will change (upstream) still.
```using GeoDataFrames; const GDF=GeoDataFrames
using DataFrames

coords = zip(rand(10), rand(10))
df = DataFrame(geom=createpoint.(coords), name="test");
GDF.write("test_points.shp", df)```

elements.text: . It's a simple wrapper on top of ArchGDAL that should make things easier. I saw a lot of questions/posts/issues on Slack/Discourse/Github on how to write shapefiles etc, while I needed a similar thing as well. It's still a work in progress, things will change (upstream) still.

using GeoDataFrames; const GDF=GeoDataFrames
using DataFrames

coords = zip(rand(10), rand(10))
df = DataFrame(geom=createpoint.(coords), name="test");
GDF.write("test_points.shp", df)

text: [ANN] FlatGeobuf 0.1 has been released :tada: . <https://github.com/evetion/FlatGeobuf.jl>. It's a parser of the flatgeobuf format (<https://bjornharrtell.github.io/flatgeobuf/>), a replacement of shapefiles and other formats based on flatbuffers. It's a work in progress, but the basics are there.

attachments.title: FlatGeobuf
attachments.text: A performant binary encoding for geographic data based on flatbuffers

elements.text: . It's a parser of the flatgeobuf format (
), a replacement of shapefiles and other formats based on flatbuffers. It's a work in progress, but the basics are there.
